questions.text: What is altered in thyroid profile throughout pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Total T3 levels are altered throughout pregnancy.

Hormones during pregnancy:

Growth Hormone

FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone)

 Free T3,Free T4
Prolactin DHEAS(Di-Hydro EpiAndroSterone)

Testosterone,Androstenodione and cortisol

Total T3 and total T4 increase due to stimulation of thyroid tissue by hCG during early period of gestation. But there is no change in free T3 and T4 due to increase in TBG. This leads to transient fall in TSH during early weeks of gestation. The level of TSH reaches normal level during second and third trimester.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen this patient?
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by autoantibodies against intrinsic factor (IF), which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells.

questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for angina, presents to you with erectile dysfunction. You decide against prescribing sildenafil because the patient is being treated with _____
questions.solution:
The patient would be on nitrates for angina and thus should not be prescribed sildenafil as sildenafil causes dangerous potentiation of nitrate action resulting in severe hypotension.

The combination of the two drugs has a synergistic action on the intracellular cGMP levels that can result in uninhibited vasodilation and a precipitous fall in blood pressure. Hence, the use of sildenafil is a contraindication when on nitrates.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a hypopigmented patch on her face with fine scaling. There is a history of atopy in the family.  What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of age, fine scaling, distribution of the lesions and history of atopy suggests the diagnosis pityriasis alba.

  • Pityriasis Alba is a pattern of dermatitis in which hypopigmentation is the most conspicuous feature.
  • It is seen in the age group of 3 to 16 years.
  • The individual lesion is a rounded oval or irregular hypopigmented patch, which is usually not well marginated and lesions have scaling.
  • In children, the lesions are often confined to the face and are most common on the cheeks and around the mouth and chin.
  • Pityriasis alba is often a manifestation of atopic eczema but it is not confined to atopic individuals.

questions.text: A patient comes with a ​history of clean-cut injury which is not lacerated. He says that he received his last dose of tetanus vaccination about 10 years ago. What should be given next?
questions.solution:
A single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the wound is clean and the last dose was received more than 10 years ago.

Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus:

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

  1. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.
  2. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.
  3. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.
  4. Unknown or never taken immunization

C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with chronic pain in his hand, knees, and hips,aggravated on climbing stairs, while pain in his hands increases when he writes or types. He also complains of stiffness in his joints in the morning, which lasts for around half an hour. On examination of the hands, Herbeden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible. X-ray of the knee showed narrowed joint space with osteophytes. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of osteoarthritis (OA).

 Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in persons aged over 45 years. The early phases typically present with episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, the pain becomes continuous and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes. Clinical signs include: 

  • Tenderness of the joint
  • Bony swelling
  • Decreased and painful range of movement 
  • Crepitus when the joint is moved
  • Weakness and wasting of muscles acting on the joint
  • Signs of inflammation 
  • Deformity and instability in severe cases

 The joints involved in osteoarthritis are:

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip
  • Knee
  • First metatarsal phalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

The wrist, elbow, and ankle joints are usually spared.Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively.

The characteristic features of OA seen on plain radiographs are:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts
  • Loose bodies and chondrocalcinosis

The image below is an X-ray of osteorthritis showing the presence of osteophytes, narrowing of the joint space (arrow), and subchondral bone sclerosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman known case of rheumatoid arthritis since 10 years presents to the OPD  with headache, nausea, vomiting, generalized weakness,  severe abdominal pain. She also complained of dark-colored urine since 3 days. On examination there was severe pallor and BP was found to be 180/120 mmHg. She is on phenacetin-caffeine- aspirin combination painkiller for 10 years. A CT abdomen was done. The patient is most likely suffering from_________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of chronic kidney disease caused due to analgesic nephropathy. The CT scan shows papillary calcifications.

Analgesic nephropathy is a renal disease characterized by chronic interstitial nephritis and renal papillary necrosis occurring due to excessive prolonged use of a combination of analgesics. It is mainly caused by the phenacetin-Aspirin-caffeine combination. Females are more commonly affected. The mechanism of injury is medullary hypoxia leading to papillary necrosis and finally causes chronic tubulointerstitial disease. It increases the risk of urothelial malignancies. Papillary calcifications are seen on CT.

NSAID induced nephropathy is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. The features are oliguric AKI, FeNa less than one, and hyperkalemia. It is seen within a few days of use and is reversible. 

Uric acid nephropathy/tumor lysis syndrome presents with oliguric AKI due to intratubular obstruction by uric acid crystals.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall onto an outstretched hand. Identify the cast given below that was used to manage the patient's injury.
questions.solution:
The cast applied to a patient in the glass-holding position is known as the scaphoid cast/glass-holding cast. It is used to treat scaphoid fractures.

To apply a scaphoid cast, the wrist is held in slight dorsiflexion and the thumb is in abduction and slight flexion, as if a glass is being held between the index finger and thumb. It extends from just below the elbow to just proximal to the metacarpal necks of the digits. On the thumb, the cast extends to just proximal to the interphalangeal joint.

Scaphoid fracture presents with pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist. A fall on an outstretched hand could result in such a fracture. The fracture can be confirmed (when an x-ray does not show a fracture) if there is pain elicited in the anatomical snuff box on the radial border of the wrist.

An oblique x-ray of the wrist should be able to show a scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: What is the indication for the procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
The given procedure is McDonald's cerclage which is done for cervical incompetence. 

Cervical incompetence is the impairment of the retentive power of the cervix. It can be due to anatomical causes or functional causes. It leads to painless dilation of the cervix and painless expulsion of the products of conception in the mid-trimester.  Cervical incompetence is diagnosed by clinical examination and ultrasonography showing the presence of short cervix (<25 mm) with or without funnelling of the internal os.

Prophylactic cerclage is done around 14 weeks of pregnancy or 2 weeks earlier than the previous fetal loss. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation.

Removal of cerclage should be done by 37 weeks of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labor or if signs of abortion are seen.

Commonly used types of procedures for cervical cerclage during pregnancy:

  • McDonald's procedure: purse-string suture
  • Modified Shirodkar's procedure:

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with breathlessness and fatigue for 5 months. Chest X-ray showed left atrial enlargement with straightening of the left cardiac border. Echocardiogram showed reduced opening of the mitral valve during diastole with thickening of the valve leaflets. Which among the following findings can be heard during auscultation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral stenosis (MS), and a mid-diastolic murmur can be heard during auscultation.

MS is a valvular heart disease, most commonly caused by rheumatic fever. Other causes include:

  • Mitral annular calcification with leaflet involvement
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Left atrial myxoma
  • Infective endocarditis with large vegetation

Chronic inflammation causes the thickening of the valve leaflets and the shortening and fusion of chordae tendineae, leading to the formation of a funnel-shaped or fish-mouth valve. Calcification immobilizes the leaflets and narrows the valve further. Thrombi are also commonly formed from the calcified valve or dilated left atrium (in atrial fibrillation).

Patients present with dyspnea and cough in the early stages. But as the disease progresses, daily activities are limited and the patient develops orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Hemoptysis can occur due to the rupture of pulmonary-bronchial venous connections as a result of pulmonary venous hypertension.

Important auscultatory findings of MS include:

  • Mid-diastolic murmur following OS:
    • Low-pitched, rumbling
    • Heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral position
    • Accentuated by mild exercise
    • Duration of the murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis
    • Reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole in patients with sinus rhythm (presystolic accentuation)
  • Opening snap (OS) of the mitral valve following the aortic component of S2 (A2)
  • Accentuated and slightly delayed first heart sound (S1)

When the cardiac output is severely reduced, the typical auscultatory findings may not be heard. This is known as silent MS. Hepatomegaly, pedal edema, ascites, and pleural effusion, may occur in patients with right ventricular failure.

Other associated murmurs include:

  • Pansystolic murmur of functional tricuspid regurgitation:
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Louder during inspiration and reduces during forced expiration (Carvallo’s sign)
  • Graham Steell murmur of pulmonary regurgitation:
    • High-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo-blowing murmur
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension

Other options:

Option B:

An ejection mid-systolic murmur can be auscultated in aortic stenosis. It begins after S1, increases in intensity toward the middle of ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is low-pitched, rough, and rasping in character. It is best heard at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.

Option C:

A pansystolic murmur of at least grade III/VI intensity can be auscultated in chronic severe mitral regurgitation. It is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Ruptured chordae tendineae may produce a murmur with a cooing or “seagull” quality, whereas a flail leaflet may produce a murmur with a musical quality. 

S1 is generally absent or soft. 

Option D:

An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic aortic regurgitation. It is high-pitched and blowing in character. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. It may be accompanied by a mid-systolic ejection murmur in isolated AR or the Austin Flint murmur in severe AR. The latter is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling, mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream.

A2 is usually absent.

questions.text: A 28-year-old HIV positive patient presents to the clinic with a history of a mild burning sensation in his mouth that is aggravated while eating spicy foods. The oral examination showed creamy white patches on the oral mucosa. The wet mount microscopy of the scraping obtained from the patches is given below. What is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of creamy white patches on the oral mucosa and the wet mount microscopy showing budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are suggestive of oral candidiasis caused by candida.

The risk factors for oral candidiasis include AIDS, diabetes mellitus, and other immunocompromised states.

Treatment: Topical azoles or nystatin.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presented to the psychiatric OPD with low mood, loss of energy,  loss of interest in pleasurable activities, decreased sleep, and appetite for the past 2 months. What is the most appropriate treatment to be started?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette point towards major depressive disorder. SSRIs like fluoxetine are the most appropriate treatment for major depressive disorder. SSRIs should be continued for 6-9 months after complete remission of symptoms in case of a single episode of depression. 

The diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are as follows:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. At least one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  • Depressed mood most of the day
  • Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  • Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  • Insomnia or hypersomnia
  • Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  • Fatigue or loss of energy
  • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  • Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  • Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaf­fective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Treatment of depression according to NICE guidelines: 

  • In recent‐onset, mild depression, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is preferred and antidepressants are not recommended.
  • Antidepressants (SSRIs) are recommended for the treatment of moderate to severe depression and for dysthymia along with CBT.
  • For treatment‐resistant depression, recommended strategies include augmentation with lithium or an antipsychotic or the addition of a second antidepressant.
  • The use of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is supported in severe and treatment-resistant depression.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the given image?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph is volar Barton’s fracture. Dislocation of the radiocarpal joint is the hallmark of Barton's fracture.

Volar-type Barton's is a fracture-dislocation of the volar rim of the radius. This type is the most common.

Dorsal-type Barton's is a fracture-dislocation of the dorsal rim of the radius. Thus, it is similar to Smith’s fracture, but the difference is that the fracture line runs obliquely and extends into the joint surface.

A Colles' fracture is a type of fracture of the distal forearm in which the broken end of the radius is bent backwards. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, deformity, and bruising. Complications may include damage to the median nerve. It typically occurs as a result of a fall on an outstretched hand.

A Smith's fracture, also sometimes known as a reverse Colles' fracture or Goyrand-Smith's, is a fracture of the distal radius. It is caused by a direct blow to the dorsal forearm or falling onto flexed wrists, as opposed to a Colles' fracture which occurs as a result of falling onto wrists in extension.

Bennett fracture is a fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone which extends into the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. This intra-articular fracture is the most common type of fracture of the thumb, and is nearly always accompanied by some degree of subluxation or frank dislocation of the carpometacarpal joint.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent blood in stools for the past 3 months. After a detailed workup, the surgeon discovers a rectal adenocarcinoma which is located 8 cm away from the anal verge. There is no nodal or distant metastasis. Which of the following surgeries would you prefer in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Low anterior resection is the preferred surgery in the rectal carcinoma which is located at least 5- 5.5 cm away from the anal verge. 

It is not performed:

  • If adequate margin could not be achieved even after preoperative chemoradiotherapy.
  • If the sphincters have to be sacrificed to achieve an adequate margin.
  • In patients who cannot tolerate low anastomosis.

In such cases, where anterior resection cannot be performed in distal rectal cancers, abdominoperineal resection is done.

questions.text: Which one of the following has maximum ionisation potential?
questions.solution:
Alpha particle is similar to helium with two protons and two neutron has maximum ionising potential but least penetrating ability and penetrates only superficial tissues to extent of 1 mm.

Gamma rays have the maximum tissue penetrating ability.

questions.text: The milestone shown in the image should disappear by_______.
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is hand regard. It should disappear by 20 weeks. 

Between 12 and 20 weeks, the child observes his own hands very intently, this is known as hand regard.

Its persistence after 20 weeks is considered abnormal.

questions.text: What is the target Maternal mortality rate and Under 5 mortality rate to be achieved by 2030 ?
questions.solution:
The target maternal mortality rate and Under-5 mortality rate to be achieved by 2030 are 70 and 25, respectively.

SDG(Sustainable development goals) comprises of 17 goals and 170 targets for Agenda 2030.

The SDGs adopted in 2015 aim to reduce Under-5 mortality to as low as 25 per 1000 live births by the year 2030.

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), also known as the Global Goals, were adopted by the United Nations in 2015 as a call to action to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure that by 2030 all people enjoy peace and prosperity.

It consists of 17 integrated sustainable development goals to be achieved by the year 2030, with priority being given to countries that are farthest behind. The SDGs are designed to end poverty, hunger, AIDS, and discrimination against women and girls.

SDG 3 deals with ensuring healthy lives and promoting well-being for all at all ages. The important sub-targets of SDG 3 are:

Sub-target Goal
3.1 Reduce global maternal mortality to <70/100,000 live births.
3.2
  • Reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12/1000 live births.
  • Reduce under 5 mortality to at least as low as 25/1000 live births.
3.3 End epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, and neglected tropical diseases, combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, and other communicable diseases
3.5 Prevention and treatment of substance abuse, narcotic abuse, and harmful use of alcohol.
3.7 Universal access to sexual and reproductive health care services, including family planning.
3.9 Substantially reduce deaths and illnesses due to hazardous chemicals and air, water, and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?

choices.text: Bladder training (with reward for delaying micturition during daytime)
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of nocturnal enuresis. Bell and pad based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment.

Nocturnal enuresis refers to the occurrence of involuntary urination at night after 5 years of age. It may be a normal phenomenon in children up to 5 years of age.

Treatment for nocturnal enuresis may include either behavioural therapy, pharmacotherapy, or psychotherapy.

Behavioural therapy:

  • Classic conditioning with the bell (or buzzer) and pad (alarm) apparatus is the most effective treatment for enuresis.
  • Dryness is achieved in 50% of the cases.
  • Bladder training with encouragement or reward for delaying micturition for increasing times during waking hours is useful but considered as an inferior to bell and pad.

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Medications should be considered if behavioural therapy has failed, and if enuresis is causing impairment in social, family, and school function.
  • Desmopressin (an antidiuretic) and Reboxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) are commonly used drugs. Reboxetine is considered as a safer alternative to imipramine.

Psychotherapy:

  • It is indicated in cases with chronic enuresis, to deal with any coexisting psy­chiatric problems and the emotional and family difficulties.

questions.text:
Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhoea with their respective lab findings.
Condition Lab markers 
1. Sheehan's syndrome A. Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol
2. Premature Ovarian failure B. High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
3. PCOS C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
4. Asherman's syndrome D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Condition Lab markers 
1. Sheehan's syndrome C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
2. Premature Ovarian failure D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
3. PCOS B. High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
4. Asherman's syndrome A. Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol

Secondary amenorrhoea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.

Premature Ovarian failure or premature menopause is the development of menopause before the age of 40 years. It is diagnosed when at least 2 serum FSH levels are elevated (>40 mIU/l) when measured at least 1 month apart in a woman <40 years. The other findings consistent with POF include low estradiol and an elevated FSH/LH ratio.

Asherman's syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium, most commonly as a result of trauma to the endometrium following pregnancy-related curettages. Oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae. The laboratory investigations and hormonal assays are generally normal in isolated cases of uterine synechiae. Diagnosis is generally established using hysteroscopy. Moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome. Treatment is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

PCOS is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrone(E1) levels are elevated but estradiol level in PCOS is low in comparison to Estrone (E1). 

Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy is hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it's called Sheehan's syndrome. Affected women may present with panhypopituitarism and may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to the deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to the deficiency of gonadotropins).

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: In a patient pO2 is 85mmHg, pCO2 is 50mmHg, pH is 7.2, and HCO3- is 36mmol/L. The condition is______

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The provided scenario describes a patient with pO₂ of 85 mmHg, pCO₂ of 50 mmHg, pH of 7.2, and HCO₃⁻ of 36 mmol/L. These findings suggest respiratory acidosis with a compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.2 indicates acidosis.

Step 2: pCO2 is 50 mmHG, which is high, thus, along with a low pH this signifies respiratory acidosis

Step 3: The HCO3- levels are increased (>30mmol/L), which is opposite to the change in pH, thus, there is compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

Step 4: Even though the compensatory mechanisms try to bring up the pH to the normal level, the pH is still below the normal value, which means that the respiratory acidosis is uncompensated.

Thus, the best option is respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase is not a component of the qSOFA score. 

qSOFA scoring is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting as it does not require laboratory values.

The qSOFA assigns one point for each component and suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two of the following parameters are met.

  • Altered mental status (GCS <15)
  • Systolic blood pressure ≤ 100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22 breaths/min.

A qSOFA score of ≥2 is associated with a significant risk of death or prolonged ICU stay.

SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system which is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting. This includes:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room after a head-on motor vehicle collision. He is unresponsive even to painful stimuli and is apneic; however, he does have a pulse. Which of the following clinical findings would exclude a diagnosis of brain death?
questions.solution:
Constricted pupils would rule out brain death.

Brain death is the irreversible cessation of all cerebral function with the preservation of cardiac activity and maintenance of respiratory and somatic function by artificial means. 

The diagnosis of brain death should be confirmed with the following clinical findings:

  • Brainstem damage as evidenced by dilated or mid-sized pupils without light reaction.
  • Absent brain-originating motor response, including response to pain stimulus above the neck or other brain-originating movements (eg, seizures, decerebrate or decorticate posturing)
  • Unresponsiveness to any stimuli,
  • Absent corneal, gag and oculovestibular reflexes, Absent sucking or rooting reflexes, Absent cough with tracheal suctioning
  • Apnea, indicating medullary destruction.
  • The heart rate should be invariant and does not accelerate to atropine.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the effect of the mutation causing sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Sickle cell anemia is characterized by the replacement of glutamate by valine at the 6th position.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to the T-to-A point mutation in the sixth codon of the β-globin gene. This results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This leads to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Painful bone crisis- hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    • Adolescence or early adulthood- auto splenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features include priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

 The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled RBCs on peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike.

Disease-modifying drugs such as hydroxyurea can be given to patients with sickle cell anemia since it reduces the incidence of adverse vaso-occlusive vents. Blood transfusions are used to treat and prevent complications of sickle cell disease, including preparation for surgery, symptomatic anemia, acute stroke, multi-organ failure, and acute chest syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, contralateral  temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, epistaxis
Conductive hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, epistaxis

questions.solution:
Trotter’s triad seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma consists of conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis.

In nasopharyngeal carcinoma, the tumour's location near these cranial nerves can lead to their compression or infiltration, resulting in the characteristic symptoms of Trotter's triad. Therefore, cranial nerves V (trigeminal nerve) and X (vagus nerve) are commonly affected in this condition.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, a malignancy arising from the nasopharynx, can manifest with Trotter's triad, which includes:

  • Conductive deafness: This occurs due to obstruction or dysfunction of the eustachian tube, leading to impaired middle ear function.
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia: This symptom is characterized by sharp, shooting pain in the temporoparietal region of the head. It is primarily caused by the involvement of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which carries sensory fibres from the face and certain parts of the head.
  • Palatal paralysis: This condition results from the involvement of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), which innervates the muscles of the soft palate. Palatal paralysis can lead to difficulty in swallowing, nasal regurgitation of fluids, and a nasal voice quality

questions.text: A patient has been brought to your emergency department with the following signs and symptoms - Dry mouth, irrelevant slurred speech, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical syndrome in the question is that of Datura poisoning.

  • Jimson weed (Datura stramonium) and angel’s trumpet (Datura candida).

  • All Datura species contain the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine.

  • Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked and produce delirium, hallucinations, and seizures along with other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia.

  • Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion; thus gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.

  • Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholine esterase antagonist, is an effective treatment for severe anticholinergic poisoning.

questions.text: Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis  is done in many countries to protect the home population.  What form of prevention is this?
questions.solution:
Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis is an example of Prospective screening, which is a form of primary prevention.   

Prospective screening is done for the benefit of others, who have not gotten the disease. This is done so that the disease is controlled and not spread. Thus, it is a form of primary prevention. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection, and people are screened for their own benefits of early diagnosis of diseases existing in them. This is a form of secondary prevention. e.g., neonatal screening for hypothyroidism, pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

questions.text:
Match the following ocular examination findings with their pathology.
  1. Wessely's immune ring
  2. Vossius ring 
  3. Arcus lipoides
  4. Kayser-Fleischer ring
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

Image A: Vossius ring
Image B: Arcus lipoides
Image C: Kayser-Fleischer ring
Image D: Wessely's immune ring

Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens as shown below. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

Arcus senilis (AS) or arcus lipoides/Gerontoxon.is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral corneal that forms a light grey or bluish ring. AS is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma. Characteristically it is separated from the margin by a narrow zone of comparatively clear cornea.

It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition. When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder.

Arcus senilis is shown in the image below.

Intraocular deposition of copper is seen in Wilson's disease and would result in a KF ring/ Kayser-Fleischer ring on the cornea. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

The immune ring of Wessely is formed by infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion in fungal corneal ulcers. It is due to a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).

The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the immune cells, inciting further inflammation.

The given shows an ulcer in the cornea and the adjacent immune ring of Wessely.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman was advised mammography for the presence of a lump in her right breast. According to the mammogram findings, the lump was categorized as BIRADS 3. What will be the next appropriate step in this patient?
questions.solution:
The next appropriate step in this patient will be to follow up the patient every 6 months for the next 2 years.

A Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) score of 3 means that it is a probably benign lesion. The next step should be a close follow-up every 6 months for the next 2 years. During this period, the score can either be downgraded to BIRADS 2 or upgraded to BIRADS 4 or 5.

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

4 Suspicious abnormality (2%-95% malignant) Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy (>95% malignant) Appropriate action should be taken

questions.text: A 20-year old male come to casualty with head injury. Examination reveals normal consciousness and blood in the tympanic membrane. Most likely cause is?
questions.solution:
Hemotympanum is a feature of fracture of Skull Base.

Anterior Cranial Fossa Fracture:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Carotico-cavernous fistula
  • Periorbital hematoma or raccoon eyes

Middle Cranial Fossa Fracture:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies
